Award.AwardTitle: Mechanism of nitric oxide synthase regulation by interdomain FMN/heme docking
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this award from the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry, Dr. Changjian Feng, from the University of New Mexico Health Sciences Center, will investigate the mechanism of action of the enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS). This flavo-hemoprotein is responsible for the biosynthesis of nitric oxide (NO), a ubiquitous molecule involved in the regulation of several physiological processes. Eukaryotic NOS isoforms are large modular enzymes containing flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and heme domains connected by a calmodulin-binding linker. Compelling evidence shows the importance of interdomain FMN/heme docking in the regulation of NOS. However, the molecular mechanism by which the FMN domain functions in NOS catalysis is unclear. This problem will be tackled by an integrated program of pulsed electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), laser flash photolysis, and mutagenesis approaches.

Because the University of New Mexico is a Hispanic serving institution, this award will provide research opportunities to underrepresented minorities, including undergraduate students from other institutions in New Mexico and other states. Efforts will be made to reach out to institutions in which the aggregate success rate for applications to federal grants has been low historically.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this award from the Chemistry of Life Process Program in the NSF Division of Chemsitry, Dr. Changjian Feng from the University of New Mexico College of Pharamcy (PI) and Dr. Andrei Astashkin from the University of Arizona (co-PI) have investigated the mechanism of action of the nitric oxide synthase (NOS) enzymes. The protein is responsible for biosynthesis of nitric oxide, a key signaling molecule in several physiologicall processes, and is thus under tight control. However, the regulation mechanism remains unclear. The investigators tackcled the problem with their integrated program of spectroscopic and rapid kinetics approaches.  Their work has provided new insight into the molecular mechanism by which a flavin domain functions in the NOS regulation. Their findings led to explicit recognition of the conformational dynamics as an important factor in the NOS function. Assigning a major importance to the overal conformational dynamics and equilibrium in regulation of electron transport in NOS represents a paradign shift in the field. This study also has significant mechanistic implications for a large family of related enzymes. The cutting edge research has been presented at several international scientific conferences, and seven articles were published in premier journals.  

The award has been benefical for the training of seven underrepresented undergraduate and graduate students, including from other instituions in New Mexico and Montana. The NSF support has also helped to strengthen inter-departmental collaborations with faculty from the Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology. The award had a significant impact on both education and research infrastructure at the University of New Mexico, a Hispanic serving instution.
